item.title: Coronavirus: Face coverings to be mandatory on public transport
item.description: From 15 June, people in England could be fined for not wearing a covering, the transport secretary says.

item.title: George Floyd: 'Pandemic of racism' led to his death, memorial told
item.description: A memorial service in Minneapolis also saw Rev Al Sharpton vow to "change the whole system of justice".

item.title: Madeleine McCann 'assumed dead' by German prosecutors
item.description: A German man, 43, is being investigated on suspicion of murder over the British girl’s disappearance.

item.title: Coronavirus: Business Secretary Alok Sharma tests negative
item.description: The business secretary has been self-isolating at home since he became unwell on Wednesday.

item.title: Norway landslide: Buildings swept away in Alta disaster
item.description: Watch as land continues to collapse during the rescue effort.

item.title: BA refuses to meet Home Secretary over quarantine plans
item.description: The airline has declined to meet Priti Patel amid strong criticism of the UK's quarantine policy.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery: White man 'used racial slur' after shooting black jogger
item.description: A judge has ruled that there is enough evidence to try three suspects for Ahmaud Arbery's murder.

item.title: Bentley: Luxury carmaker to cut up to 1,000 jobs
item.description: The firm, which makes its cars in Crewe, says up to 1,000 jobs will go.

item.title: Vaccine summit exceeds target to raise almost £7bn
item.description: At the UK-hosted summit, Boris Johnson said up to eight millions lives will be saved by the funding.

item.title: Coronavirus: Police turn away 1,000 cars in two days
item.description: Police say many people officers spoke to were from England and thought lockdown rules were the same.

item.title: George Floyd death: Thousands join Birmingham protest
item.description: The demonstration is one of many held globally in the wake of the 46-year-old's death.

item.title: Porn star Nacho Vidal held in Spain after man dies in toad-venom ritual
item.description: Spanish police investigate Nacho Vidal over the death of a man who inhaled a psychedelic substance.

item.title: 'We're all still grieving' - care home staff on impact of virus
item.description: Care home staff from the charity MHA look back at the impact of the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: Gaming 'hero' retires at 23 due to ill-health
item.description: Jian Zihao says physical and mental health problems have caused him to quit e-sports.

item.title: George Floyd's life mattered, says Duchess of Sussex in heartfelt message
item.description: Meghan urges young people to rebuild society after the African-American man died in police custody.

item.title: Curtis Hayes: Man behind the protest plea that moved America
item.description: In a viral speech, Curtis Hayes implored two generations of demonstrator to "find a better way".

item.title: Australian man interrupts PM Morrison to say 'get off my lawn'
item.description: The resident stopped Scott Morrison's press briefing, complaining his lawn had "just been reseeded".

item.title: South Korean balloons: Plans to stop people sending cross-border messages
item.description: The North Korean leadership has called the balloon-senders "human scum" and "mongrel dogs".

item.title: Coronavirus in Russia: 'I don't trust Putin any more'
item.description: In Russia, coronavirus has seen the long-time president's approval rating fall to an all-time low.

item.title: Life After Death: How I coped becoming a widower
item.description: Mark and Marco explain what their lives have been like since losing their partners.

item.title: Derbyshire brothers make cushions for 'tired' key workers
item.description: Ronnie, 10, and seven-year-old Reggie Cockroft want to help NHS and supermarket workers.

item.title: Sudan banned FGM - what happens next?
item.description: FGM was outlawed by Sudan's new Sovereign Council, who have been in power since August 2019.

item.title: White House likens Trump to Churchill in WW2
item.description: The press secretary compares the president to the British wartime leader inspecting bomb damage.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards: Fleabag and Game of Thrones up for 'must-see moment'
item.description: Viewers have until 15 July to cast their vote for the only Bafta TV award decided on by the public.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: False turns and a final breakthrough?
item.description: After 13 years, the hunt for the missing three year old may be a step closer to a conclusion.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are protests legal amid lockdown?
item.description: Black Lives Matter protests continue in the UK - but are they illegal under restrictions on gatherings?

item.title: Madeleine McCann case in pictures
item.description: Photographs of some of the key moments since the three-year-old went missing in Portugal in 2007.

item.title: 'My brothers on Europe's last death row'
item.description: Any day now two men may be executed in Europe's only country that still has the death penalty.

item.title: Viewpoint: What it's like to be an African in the US
item.description: Kenyan journalist Larry Madowo writes about the racism he has experienced in the US.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I may lose it all, but there’s no help for me'
item.description: Layla Barnes is one of thousands of small business owners who are getting no government support in the pandemic.

item.title: 'You audition for a show only for it to get cancelled’
item.description: With theatres closed, and TV and movie filming on hold, acting school graduates are struggling.

item.title: The 100-year wound that Hungary cannot forget
item.description: Hungary lost two-thirds of its territory in the 1920 Trianon treaty and now aims to revive its past.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can superspreading be stopped?
item.description: Identifying superspreading events could be crucial in the fight against the virus, scientists say.

item.title: George Floyd death: How many black people die in police custody in England and Wales?
item.description: George Floyd's death has sparked protests across the world and raised questions about police practice.

item.title: Chelsea in talks to sign RB Leipzig striker Werner
item.description: Chelsea are in talks to sign RB Leipzig striker Timo Werner, whose release clause is reported to be £54m.

item.title: BBC to show highlights of every England Test and ODI this summer
item.description: The BBC will show highlights of every Test and one-day international played by England this summer.

item.title: Friday's gossip: Leicester's Chilwell tempted by Chelsea interest
item.description: Ben Chilwell is tempted by Chelsea interest, Liverpool will not rival the Blues in their pursuit of Timo Werner, plus more.

item.title: NBA: Disney World Resort set to host rest of 2020 season
item.description: The remainder of the NBA season will be played at Florida's Disney World Resort from 31 July.

item.title: Brees asks for forgiveness over 'hurtful and insensitive' comments
item.description: New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees says "it breaks my heart to know the pain I have caused" after opposing NFL kneeling protests.

item.title: Drivers could miss part of race weekend if mechanics test positive
item.description: A driver could have to miss part of a race weekend if one of his mechanics tests positive for coronavirus when the season resumes, Ross Brawn says.

item.title: Premier League approves five substitutions for rest of season
item.description: Premier League teams will be able to make five substitutions, rather than the usual three, in each match to the end of the season.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: Face coverings are to become compulsory for people using public transport in England.

item.title: Can I start a new relationship? And other questions
item.description: Starting a new relationship is difficult during the current crisis, but not impossible.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are the first to go back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England in June, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: Parents shamed for back-to-school choices
item.description: Parents of year six and year one pupils have been falling out over whether to send them back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe is it to get on a plane?
item.description: Many airlines are planning to resume flying, but they first need to reduce the risks of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: A cluster of islands: How Shetland locked down early and stopped the virus in its tracks
item.description: Shetland was one of the UK areas worst hit by Covid-19 - now there have been no new cases for six weeks. How did they do it?
